BMBLx exhibited significant venom specificity in vitro and in vivo, andcounteredLTxR-mediated revascularization of arterial thrombosis in a murine model of atherosclerosis (Figures 7A-C). We then investigated the therapeutic potential of BMBLx in a mouse model of cerebral ischemia/reperfusion injury (IRI), a common cause of stroke, in which the absence of blood flow leads to ischemic injury and subsequent restoration of blood flow results in reperfusion injury. In this model, BMBLx treatment attenuated infarct volume (Figures 7Da-E) and improved neurological function (Figures 7F-G) 24 h after IRI. Importantly, BMBLx treatment also improved long-term neurobehavioral outcomes, as assessed by the rotarod test at day 14 (Figure 7H) and the Morris water maze test at day 28 (Figures 7I-J). BMBLx treatment was also associated with decreased levels of TNF-a and IL-12 in the brain at 24 h after IRI (Figure 7K), indicating a reduction in neuroinflammation. Taken together, these findings suggest that BMBLx is a promising therapeutic candidate for the treatment of IRI.
